channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia-Ukraine War: Putin Remains Silent on Crash of Plane Linked to Mercenary Leader
item.description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, who led a brief mutiny in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed. There was no confirmation that he had died, and Russian officials including President Vladimir V. Putin did not comment on the incident.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: ‘Aren’t You a Man?’: How Russia Goads Citizens Into the Army
item.description: The Times tracked several months of Russian state messaging in the Kremlin’s effort to recruit soldiers.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski, Alina Lobzina, Sarah Kerr and Natalie Reneau

item.title: The BRICS Group Announces New Members, Expanding Its Reach
item.description: Argentina, Egypt, Ethiopia, Iran, the U.A.E. and Saudi Arabia have been invited to join the club of emerging nations, strengthening its role as a geopolitical alternative to Western-led forums.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The BRICS club of emerging nations announced plans to add new members on Thursday.

item.title: Thailand’s Old Guard Keeps Its Grip After Voters Seek Change
item.description: The country went months without naming a new prime minister, only for Parliament to elect Srettha Thavisin, a candidate that many frustrated voters say represents the establishment.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Pita Limjaroenrat, the Move Forward Party leader, center with microphone, at a rally in Pattaya, Thailand, last month.

item.title: Japan Starts Releasing Radioactive Fukushima Water
item.description: China said it would suspend imports of Japanese seafood in response to what it has called an unsafe plan to dispose of the wastewater.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daichi nuclear power plant on Thursday.

item.title: Dissident Who Fled China by Jet Ski Said to Have Planned Escape for Years
item.description: Officials in South Korea aren’t saying who crossed 200 miles of ocean to reach its shores. But people who know Kwon Pyong say it wasn’t his first audacious move.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korea Coast Guard, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: South Korea’s Coast Guard, which released this image, said it had detained a man who was found stranded with this vehicle off the country’s west coast last week.

item.title: Ex-Principal of Australian Girls School Sentenced to 15 Years for Abuse
item.description: Malka Leifer, extradited from Israel after a lengthy process, was found guilty in April of sexually abusing two students decades earlier.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Malka Leifer at a courtroom in Jerusalem in 2018.

item.title: What to Know About Zimbabwe’s Presidential Election
item.description: The country needs a free and fair election to escape Western sanctions. But voting got off to a rough start, with late openings at polling places and fliers spreading misinformation.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Moyo, Tendai Marima and John Eligon
item.category: Citizens Coalition for Change (Zimbabwean Political Party)
item.media:description: Registering to vote at a polling station in Mbare, Zimbabwe, a suburb of the capital Harare, on Wednesday. Voters encountered frustrating delays as voting began.

item.title: How Multiple Warnings About Killer Nurse Lucy Letby Were Missed
item.description: Since the trial of Lucy Letby, a nurse who murdered babies in her care, experts have warned of a culture of hostility toward whistle-blowers in Britain’s National Health Service.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: The Countess of Chester Hospital in Chester, England, where Lucy Letby worked. She was convicted of murdering premature infants.

item.title: Toto Cutugno, Singer Whose ‘L’Italiano’ Struck a Chord, Dies at 80
item.description: The nostalgic ballads and catchy pop songs he wrote paved the way for an international career. He sold more than 100 million albums worldwide.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Toto Cutugno in 1983, the year of his hugely popular song “L’Italiano.”

item.title: In Photos: Greece’s Catastrophic Wildfires
item.description: Firefighters are struggling to quell deadly flames, part of a crisis of wildfires in the nation this summer. Here are photos from the latest blazes.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Firefighters near Mount Parnitha in Athens early on Thursday.

item.title: At Least 26 Die as Bridge Collapses While Under Construction in India
item.description: A rescue effort was underway as reports indicated that several additional workers were trapped under the wreckage.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Zoramthanga, via X, formerly known as Twitter
item.media:description: A photo shared on social media by Mizoram State, India, showed the damaged bridge.

item.title: How the Pakistan Cable Car Passengers Were All Rescued Safely
item.description: Eight people, including seven students heading to a nearby school, were saved after being stranded for hours hundreds of feet above a valley in a remote, mountainous region of Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Salman Masood
item.media:description: As a helicopter attempts to bring a rescuer closer, the local mayor said, “Wind from the rotor would jolt and unsettle the chairlift, causing the children to cry out in fear.”

item.title: A Saudi Rolex Sold in a U.S. Mall Could Get Bolsonaro Arrested
item.description: Brazil’s former president, Jair Bolsonaro, is the target of multiple criminal investigations. One includes a watch, gifted by the Saudis, sold in a Pennsylvania mall.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jair Bolsonaro, the former Brazilian president, denies wrongdoing in each of the investigations into him, saying the allegations are fabrications that amount to political persecution.

item.title: What We Know About the Plane Crash Linked to Wagner Chief Prigozhin
item.description: The Wagner mercenary group leader, who staged a short-lived mutiny against Russia’s military leadership in June, was listed as a passenger on a plane that crashed on Wednesday. Here’s what to know.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg

item.title: Face of Jacobite Hero ‘Bonnie Prince Charlie’ Recreated From Death Masks
item.description: The prince, Charles Edward Stuart, led a Jacobite rising in the Scottish Highlands in 1745. A new recreation of his face seeks to humanize the man behind the legend.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil

item.title: A Russian Court Extends the Pretrial Detention of Journalist Evan Gershkovich
item.description: A Moscow court on Thursday extended the pretrial detention of the American reporter, who has denied the espionage charges he faces. The U.S. says he has been wrongfully detained.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova

item.title: Ukraine Observes Independence Day With Subdued Celebrations
item.description: The Ukrainian authorities said the national holiday, which comes exactly 18 months after Russia’s full-scale invasion, won’t include public celebrations amid concerns about Russian attacks.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times

item.title: 4 Dead in Shooting at Cook’s Corner Bar in Orange County, California
item.description: At least six others were injured at a bar in eastern Orange County, Calif., that has attracted motorcyclists and been a community hub for decades.
item.dc:creator: Shawn Hubler, Mike Ives and John Yoon

item.title: Prigozhin, Wagner Leader, Believed to Be on Plane in Deadly Russia Crash
item.description: All 10 people on a jet linked to Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the founder of the mercenary group, were killed on Wednesday, Russian officials said.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A photograph released by the Russian government on Wednesday shows first responders at the site of a plane crash near the village of Kuzhenkino, in Russia’s Tver region.

item.title: North Korea’s 2nd Satellite Launch Fails to Reach Orbit
item.description: The ​rocket failure was an embarrassment for the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who badly needed a morale booster for his people.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: A television in Seoul on Wednesday showed file footage of North Korea’s second rocket launch, which ended in failure.

item.title: Warren Hoge, Who Covered Wars and World Crises for The Times, Dies at 82
item.description: A correspondent and bureau chief, he wrote vividly from all corners of the globe before rising in newsroom leadership as foreign editor and assistant managing editor.
item.dc:creator: Robert D. McFadden
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times
item.media:description: Warren Hoge in 1976, the year he was hired by The Times to be a reporter on the metropolitan desk, covering New York-area news.

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Prigozhin Listed Aboard Crashed Plane
item.description: Also, a paralyzed woman regains her voice.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the head of the Wagner Private Military Company, leaving Rostov-on-Don, Russia, after his aborted mutiny in June of this year.

item.title: Atop an Underwater Hot Spring, an ‘Octopus Garden’ Thrives
item.description: The heat, a new study suggests, makes for an ideal breeding ground for these eight-legged animals.
item.dc:creator: Katrina Miller

item.title: BRICS May Add More Countries to the Group. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: Saudi Arabia, Argentina, Indonesia and Egypt are among the potential candidates to expand the five-nation bloc, many of them seeking stronger ties with non-Western powers. Iran is also interested.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Natalie Alcoba, Farnaz Fassihi and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Leaders and diplomats from Brazil, China, South Africa, India and Russia at the BRICS conference in Johannesburg on Wednesday.

item.title: Greece Battles Its Most Widespread Wildfires on Record
item.description: Extreme heat has turned much of the country into a tinderbox. More than 350 fires have broken out in the past five days, the government said.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: Firefighters in Chasia, on the outskirts of Athens, on Tuesday. Of the many fires, the fronts in the north and near Athens were considered the most dangerous.

item.title: Putin Again Blames West for Ukraine War In Speech to BRICS Summit
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin said Russia would assume chairmanship of the group made up of Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa next year and host a summit in the city of Kazan in October 2024.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia delivering remarks via video link, during a summit of BRICS nations in Johannesburg on Wednesday.

item.title: China Works to Expand its Sway in Africa Amid Rivalry With the U.S.
item.description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, pitches his country as a leader of the developing world, rallying support for an alternative to the U.S.-dominated global order.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, the Chinese leader, with President Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa in Pretoria on Tuesday.

item.title: In the Heart of the Australian Outback, Safeguarding a Sacred Land
item.description: On a road trip in central Australia, a visitor learns how Indigenous custodians and conservationists are working to protect an ancient land and its animal denizens.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Ham

item.title: Russia Says Ukrainian Drones Targeted Moscow for a Sixth Consecutive Day
item.description: Drone attacks in Russian territory have become more frequent as Ukraine wages a grueling counteroffensive.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Valeriya Safronova
item.media:description: Inspecting the damaged building in Moscow on Wednesday.

item.title: Canadian Officials Condemn Facebook for News Ban as Wildfires Burn
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said it was “inconceivable” that the platform had responded to a new licensing law by blocking news links, as the country confronts its worst wildfire season on record.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin
item.media:description: Smoke from wildfires enveloped Kelowna, British Columbia, on Friday.

item.title: At BRICS Summit, Putin Tries to Rally Support
item.description: Leaders of Brazil, India, China and South Africa addressed other topics, but Russia’s president, unable to attend in person because he is wanted for war crimes, put the war in Ukraine at center stage in the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the BRICS summit remotely on Tuesday. Under indictment by the International Criminal Court, Mr. Putin faces arrest if he travels to South Africa.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: A Dangerous Rescue in Pakistan
item.description: Also, exploring street food in Fukuoka, Japan.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Six children and two adults were suspended for several hours inside a cable car and rescued by a military helicopter in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa province, Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: As West Bank Shootings Rise, Israel’s Government Vows to Retaliate
item.description: An apparently unarmed Palestinian man and an Israeli teacher were among the recent victims. Israel’s government has pledged to strike at Palestinian assailants.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli forces blocked a road after a father and son were shot in the West Bank town of Huwara on Saturday.

item.title: Canadian Wildfires Twice as Likely Because of Climate Change, Study Finds
item.description: Climate change has made hot, dry and windy conditions like those that fueled this year’s blazes at least twice as common as they would otherwise be.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Daryann Gauthier/Société de protection des forêt, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Wildfire smoke in northern Quebec last month.

item.title: Ukraine’s Forces and Firepower Are Misallocated, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: American strategists say Ukraine’s troops are too spread out and need to concentrate along the counteroffensive’s main front in the south.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Julian E. Barnes, Helene Cooper and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian marines training in the Zaporizhzhia region before heading to the frontline. American officials say more Ukrainian forces should be near Zaporizhzhia and in the south of the country.

item.title: European Climate Czar Steps Down to Take Part in Dutch Elections
item.description: Frans Timmermans is stepping down at a crucial time for European climate laws to become the lead candidate for a left-wing coalition in the Dutch elections in November.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Frans Timmermans at a European Commission meeting in Brussels in March.

item.title: 18 People Killed in Greek Wildfire May Be Migrants
item.description: The authorities said the bodies were found near the border with Turkey, in an area that is a crossing point for thousands of migrants seeking to enter Europe.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:description: A wildfire burning a home in the village of Avantas, near Alexandroupolis, Greece, on Monday. Gale-force winds are fanning wildfires across the country.

item.title: Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo to Visit China Next Week
item.description: The trip by Gina Raimondo, the secretary of commerce, comes at a tense moment for the U.S.-China relationship and the Chinese economy.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Gina Raimondo, the U.S. secretary of commerce, will travel to China next week, the latest high-level U.S. official to visit the country this year.

item.title: Sunflower Farm Warns Guests, ‘Keep Your Clothes On’
item.description: A summer getaway southwest of London put up signs asking people to stop posing for risqué photos where other guests, including children, could see.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses

item.title: Ukrainian Drones Are Intercepted Over Russia, Including Near Moscow
item.description: Russia said it had intercepted drones in two parts of the country, in what appeared to be the latest in a string of Ukrainian attacks intended to bring the war home to Russia’s citizens.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: The site of a reported drone attack in Krasnogorsk, a town near Moscow, on Tuesday.

item.title: Prigozhin Re-emerges in Apparent Recruitment Video
item.description: The fate and whereabouts of Yevgeny V. Prigozhin, the Wagner chief, have remained largely shrouded from public view since he led a short-lived mutiny in June.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Razgruzka Vagnera Telegram, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Yevgeny V. Prigozhin appears in an image from a video released on Monday via a Telegram channel affiliated with Wagner forces.

item.title: BRICS Summit Attracts Global Interest Not Seen in Years
item.description: The leaders from the five-member group of nations — Brazil, Russia, India, China and South Africa — are discussing expanding the club, which harbors ambitions of becoming a geopolitical alternative to Western-led forums.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Preparations for the 2023 BRICS Summit at the Sandton Convention Center in Johannesburg on Sunday.

item.title: Taliban Members Are Accused of Targeting Afghan Ex-Officials
item.description: A U.N. mission in Afghanistan reported summary killings, arbitrary detentions and torture of hundreds of onetime soldiers, police officers and others in the old government.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A Taliban security patrol in Kandahar, Afghanistan, on the second anniversary of the militants’ takeover.

item.title: Zimbabwe Voters to Elect President While Trained Workers Flee
item.description: Nurses, doctors and workers of all kinds are seeking to escape the country’s economic turmoil, an issue that has become a central theme in the election scheduled for Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Tendai Marima and John Eligon
item.media:description: Supporters of the opposition leader Nelson Chamisa during a campaign event in Harare, Zimbabwe’s capital, on Monday. Mr. Chamisa lost out to Emmerson Mnangagwa, the current president, in the 2018 election.

item.title: At Risk of Invasion or Lovely to Visit: Two Views of a Polish Border Area
item.description: Polish authorities have issued dire warnings that the Suwalki Gap, on Poland’s northern border between Russia and Belarus, is under threat. Locals say that is just election-related fear-mongering.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Kasia Strek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The town center of Suwalki, Poland, this month. Local residents say that the government’s warnings that Russian mercenaries pose a threat to the region are false.

item.title: Thai Parliament Picks Real Estate Mogul as Next Prime Minister
item.description: Months of political chaos have culminated in the selection of Srettha Thavisin, a businessman seen as amenable to royalists and the military-appointed Senate.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Srettha Thavisin at Pheu Thai Party’s headquarters in Bangkok on Tuesday. He faces the immense challenge of meeting the demands of an electorate that voted for change and is now disillusioned with his party.

item.title: Cambodia Leader, Hun Sen, Appoints Hun Manet as New Prime Minister
item.description: Gen. Hun Manet is expected to guide a generational shift in Cambodian politics, taking over for his father Hun Sen, one of the world’s longest-ruling prime ministers.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Tang Chhin Sothy/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Gen. Hun Manet, center, arriving at the National Assembly in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, on Tuesday to be elected as the country’s new prime minister.

item.title: Japan to Release Treated Water From Fukushima Nuclear Plant
item.description: In the face of regional and domestic objections, the country plans to proceed with a discharge at Fukushima that will eventually reach more than a million tons of water.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Masatsugu Shibata, a fisherman near the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant, is concerned the plan to release the water will threaten his livelihood.

item.title: British Columbia Wildfires Leave Dozens of Buildings Burned
item.description: The final tally of the damage will be higher, officials said, although no buildings have been destroyed over the past 24 hours as the fires ease.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Paige Taylor White/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Dropping water in West Kelowna, British Columbia, where about 30,000 people have been ordered to evacuate.

item.title: Elections in Ecuador and Guatemala: Four Takeaways
item.description: Outsiders overperformed, underscoring the volatility of Latin American politics. Candidates calling to emulate El Salvador’s crackdown on crime did not do well.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero, Genevieve Glatsky and Jody García
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Guatemala, the progressive anti-graft crusader Bernardo Arévalo won in a landslide over a former first lady, dealing a blow to the conservative political establishment.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Japan’s Radioactive Water
item.description: Also, Ukrainian soldiers playing video games.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant in 2019.

item.title: Dueling Tours for Influence as Ukraine War Scrambles Alliances
item.description: As Volodymyr Zelensky went on a diplomatic blitz of Europe, a top Iranian general made his way to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece in Athens on Monday. Mr. Zelensky spoke of a proposal for Greece to train Ukrainians to fly F-16 fighter jets.

item.title: Could U.S. Toughness on Chinese Business Have Unintended Consequences?
item.description: Businesses fear that efforts to look tough on Beijing, which have the potential to be more expansive than moves by the federal government, could have unintended consequences.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States (CFIUS)
item.media:credit: Lewis Ableidinger for The New York Times

item.title: Luis Rubiales Apologizes for Kissing Jennifer Hermoso After World Cup Win
item.description: “Probably I made a mistake,” Luis Rubiales, the Spanish soccer federation chief, said after grabbing Jennifer Hermoso and planting a kiss full on her mouth, igniting howls of outrage on social media.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Chaundler
item.media:description: Luis Rubiales, president of the Royal Spanish Football Federation, hugging Jennifer Hermoso after the World Cup final match in Sydney, Australia, on Sunday.

item.title: Palestinian Man’s Lawyers Say Israeli Police Marked Him With Star of David
item.description: Photos of Arwa Sheikh Ali’s cheek after his arrest showed wounds including triangular marks and lines. The police denied the accusations and said the shapes had been made by an officer’s shoelaces.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A photo released by the Israeli police showing injuries to Arwa Sheikh Ali, a Palestinian who was arrested last week.

item.title: Nuclear War Could End the World, but What if It’s All in Our Heads?
item.description: Some experts want to apply recent neuroscience research to the decision making that could lead to doomsday.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Scoles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Fake Gold on Private Plane Unfurls Mystery in Zambia and Egypt
item.description: After a plane arrived from Egypt bearing cash, weapons and what looked like gold bars, Zambia arrested 12 people. Egyptian reporters covering the case were briefly detained.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: Zambian authorities searched and seized a private jet at the international airport in the capital, Lusaka.

item.title: 1973: 35 Israeli Settlements Planned in Arab Area
item.description: Israel announced further plans to build in territories captured in the 1967 war.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Zelensky Thanks Denmark for Pledging to Donate F-16 Fighter Jets
item.description: The Netherlands and Denmark became the first countries to announce that they would donate the planes.
item.dc:creator: Enjoli Liston and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, and Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark sitting in an F-16 fighter jet at an air base in Vojens, Denmark, on Sunday.

item.title: Flight Risk
item.description: We’re covering near misses on airport runways, severe weather and the Women’s World Cup.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: LaGuardia Airport.
